text:
Coming here, I had no idea what
I wanted to do after school.

I actually reached out
to a few professors

and a few folks in CPD
to ask how much should I
try something different.

And an answer that I
got that I really liked

is that when you're trying
to scale a mountain,

you're on four support
points, your hands, your feet.

You never want to move
all four at the same time.

Maybe you move two,
maybe you move three

if you're really good, but you
never want to move all four
at a time.

At HBS, I did end up
making a career pivot,

so before I came here, I
was working in startups.

And then afterwards I'm going
to be working in big tech.

The Tech scene is very
much alive and vibrant,

and I think Tech Club
is a really good way

to get access to alums,
professors, peers who have
already worked in the industry.

People at HBS have
done everything,

and you just need to find the
person who is the right person
to talk to.

And actually CPD is
really helpful with that

because they talk
to so many people

and are exposed to so many
different career paths

that they were able to point me
to peers who I should talk to.

Yeah, I don't think our
career defines who we are.

I think it's much more
important for our career

to be coherent with who we
are and who we want to be.

You can't just think
five years out.

You need to be thinking 20
years out, 30 years out,

and it's totally OK if your
hypothesis around what you want
to do in 20, 30 years changes.

But it's really important
to have a goal in mind

as you're going
through your decisions

to find a career
that can magnify

who you are rather than
take away from who you are.

I've learned the
hard way that there

are much more important things
than what you do for your job,

that a job is just
a part of life.
It's not your whole life.
